used in Maryland's lethal injections.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff argued that the defendant's lethal injection procedures arbitrarily and unnecessarily created a grave risk that he would suffer extreme pain during his execution, thus violating his rights under the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff also filed a similar complaint in the Circuit Court for Baltimore City alleging that the defendants failed to follow Maryland law because the execution protocol had not been adopted under the Maryland Administrative Procedures Act (MAPA).[SENTMARKER]On December 19, 2006 the Maryland Court of Appeals invalidated the Maryland execution protocols until such time as they were properly adopted under MAPA or exempted from that requirement by an act of the Maryland General Assembly.[SENTMARKER]On January 29, 2007, two bills were introduced in the Maryland General Assembly, one that would exempt the death penalty protocols from the MAPA requirement and one that would repeal the death penalty in the state.[SENTMARKER]The judge agreed to stay the proceedings of this case pending the outcome of the legislation.[SENTMARKER]According to the status report on March 14, 2011, all executions in Maryland had been stayed until the proper administrative regulations were adopted.[SENTMARKER]On August 16, 2012 this case was administratively closed.[SENTMARKER]In May 2013 the Maryland legislature repealed the death penalty for all future convictions and in December 2014 Governor O'Malley commuted the death sentences of the four remaining death-row inmates to life without the possibility of parole.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In January 2002, a group of individuals with disabilities filed this class action lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania against the Township of Millcreek, Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Township violated Title II and Section 504 by failing to make certain facilities accessible to those with disabilities participating in programs, services and activities in accordance with Title II.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in November 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties entered into a Consent Decree and Partial Settlement Agreement, which was entered into by the Court on January 15, 2014.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a number of conditions, including requiring the Township to hire a certified Disadvantaged Business Enterprises (DBE) to work on certain construction projects.[SENTMARKER]The Court retained jurisdiction over the parties to enforce the terms of the consent decree and partial settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]In November 2016, the parties entered a Fourth Consent Decree, which required Millcreek to conduct a facility survey to determine whether each of the buildings and parks that are used by the Township are accessible to and usable by people with disabilities.

gold_sents: Several student members of a high school religious club brought suit against the city of said high school alleging violation of their freedom of speech, assembly, and free exercise of religion under the First Amendment's Establishment Clause and Free Exercise Clause.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also alleged unlawful discrimination based on the religious content of their speech in violation of the Equal Access Act and the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause, in addition to violation of their freedom of expression under Massachusetts state law.[SENTMARKER]On June 16, 2003, the Court entered a consent decree between the school and the plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]As per the decree, the defendants agreed to rescind punishment of the plaintiffs for the distribution of the religious materials, remove prior restraints and content-based restrictions of distribution of materials during non-instructional time without complying with substantive and procedural safeguards, so long as distribution doesn't substantially and materially disrupt the operation of the school or the new policies.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs were awarded $28,500 in attorneys' fees and costs and the case was closed.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 2, 2012, two students filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Massachusetts against the Westfield School District.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the district's literature distribution policy violated their constitutional rights to freedom of speech, free exercise of religion, and equal protection under the laws.[SENTMARKER]The district denied the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, and the case was settled on March 3, 2012.

gold_sents: On May 31, 2018, The National Federation of the Blind filed this lawsuit in the U.C.[SENTMARKER]District Court for the District of Maryland (Northern Division).[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff sued the U.S. Department of Education and the Secretary of Education along with the Acting Assistant Secretary, claiming that the changes to the 2018 OCR Manual violated the Administrative Procedure Act, 5 U.S.C. §§ 551 et seq., and was contrary to the mission of the OCR.[SENTMARKER]These changes in § 108(t) of the 2018 OCR Manual require mandatory dismissal of complaints if the claim is either part of "a pattern" of complaints against multiple recipients, or places an unreasonable burden on OCR's resources.[SENTMARKER]These changes also eliminate the appeal rights of complainants.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a settlement agreement reopening complaints dismissed under the contested rules of the manual and allowing parties that had their cases dismissed under the rule to petition the Department to reopen their cases.[SENTMARKER]The case is not officially closed until February 2021, when the parties can no longer file for further enforcement.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 31, 2018, the NAACP and its state and local units filed this suit in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]District Attorney's Office for the district of Maryland against the Office of Education for the Department of Justice (DOE) alleging that the DOE had violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (APA) by implementing a new policy that required the dismissal of complaints filed by individual complainants against multiple recipients of federal funding.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the new policy violated the APA because it required the complainants to file a complaint with the Enforcement Office Director of the DOE, which was then required to determine whether or not the complaint was part of a pattern of complaints.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement in November 2018 and the case was dismissed in March 2018.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 31, 2018, the National Federation for the Blind filed this suit in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland on behalf of members of the blind.[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the Office for civil rights (OCR) violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by mandating that complaints of illegal discrimination be handled and processed by OCR.[SENTMARKER]Specifically, the complaint alleged that OCR required that complaints be dismissed if they were part of a "pattern" of complaints by an individual complainant against multiple recipients.[SENTMARKER]The complaint also alleged that this provision was not limited to those complaints that would place an "unreasonable burden" on OCR.[SENTMARKER]In March 2018, OCR issued a revised manual, which superseded the 2015 Manual and contained new provisions requiring mandatory dismissal of certain complaints and eliminating the right of complainants to appeal determinations by OCR to the Enforcement Office Director.[SENTMARKER]The case was closed on May 31, 2018.

gold_sents: On May 14, 2020 the plaintiffs filed a lawsuit against the Department of Education (ED) in the United States District Court in the District of Maryland.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that regulations issued by ED "sharply limit educational institutions' obligations to respond to reports of sexual harassment and assault" and therefore contravened Title IX of the Education Amendmentsof 1972.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing with responses to the complaint due on July 31, 2020.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 14, 2020, a group of nonprofit organizations filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the district of Maryland against the Office of the Civil Rights of the Department of education for violating Title IX of the federal education law.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Office violated Title IX when it failed to conclude the investigation of a complaint that a student had been raped while walking home from school, assess the potential danger to the community raised by the complaint, and provide appropriate support services to the student as she struggled to continue her education.[SENTMARKER]According to one report, 68% of survivors struggle to focus in class.[SENTMARKER]The case is being handled by Seamus Curley of Stroock Stroock Lavan LLP.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On May 6, 2020, a group of women filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland against the Department of education, alleging that the agency had violated Title IX by failing to adequately address sexual harassment and assault in schools receiving federal funds.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, who were represented by the nonprofit organization Girls for Gender Equity (GGE), alleged that the Department had significantly reduced the responsibility of schools to respond to complaints of sexual harassment, assault, and discrimination on the one hand, and race, national origin, and disability, on the other.[SENTMARKER]The case was brought by GGE, COPAA, and Know Your IX, a nonprofit organization that educates students about the right to an education free from sex discrimination.[SENTMARKER]The lawsuit was filed on behalf of GGE and COPAA on May 6, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The case is pending in federal court in Maryland.

gold_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved by majority vote a statewide ballot initiative-Proposal 2-which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Both Proposal 2 and the University of Michigan's announcement that it would comply triggered litigation.[SENTMARKER]On November 15, 2012, the en banc Sixth Circuit held that Proposal 2 created a comparative structural burden that undermined the Equal Protection Clause (which the court called the "political process" argument).[SENTMARKER]Accordingly, the court found Proposal 2 unconstitutional.[SENTMARKER]On March 24, 2013, the Supreme Court granted review of the case.[SENTMARKER]Argument will be after the Court's summer break.[SENTMARKER]On October 15, 2013 the Supreme Court heard oral argument in the case.[SENTMARKER]In an opinion written by Justice Kennedy and joined by Justice Roberts and Justice Alito, the court reversed the Sixth Circuit.[SENTMARKER]There were two concurring opinions and a single dissent.[SENTMARKER]In his opinion Kennedy asserts that this is not a case about resolving the debate about racial preferences, but rather about whether it is constitutional for Michigan to allow its voters to decide the issue.[SENTMARKER]The court holds that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court’s precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions.
pegasus_output_sents: On November 8, 2006, a collection of interest groups and individuals, including the Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, Integration and Immigration Rights, and Fight for Equality By Any Means Necessary, filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Eastern district of Michigan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the provisions of Proposal 2 affecting public colleges and universities violated the Constitution and federal statutory law.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the Attorney General's Motion for Summary Judgment and dismissed the Complaint on its merits.[SENTMARKER]In 2008, the District Court granted summary judgment to Michigan, thus upholding Proposal 2.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On November 7, 2006, the people of Michigan approved a statewide ballot initiative which amended the Michigan Constitution to prohibit discrimination or preferential treatment based on race or gender in the operation of public employment, public education or public contracting in the State.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs claimed that such elections prevented African Americans from being the majority voting bloc in many districts Id.[SENTMARKER]at 2-4.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs argued that this election system unfairly discriminated against African American voters and violated the Federal Voting Rights Act and the 13th, 14th, and 15th amendments of the Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The district court held that the amendment violated the Equal Protection Clause because it violated the constitutional distinction between laws that impede minorities' efforts to obtain "equal protection" and those that preclude what the district court labeled "preferential treatment" as a means to limit the Hunter/Seattle principle.[SENTMARKER]The Sixth Circuit held that there is no authority in the Federal Constitution or in this Court's precedents for the Judiciary to set aside Michigan laws that commit to the voters the determination whether racial preferences may be considered in governmental decisions, in particular with respect to school admissions policies in higher education.[SENTMARKER]The Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit reversed the lower court's decision.

pegasus_output_sents: In April 1993, the ASAP advocacy group filed a lawsuit in the Commonwealth Court in Northern Lehigh, Pennsylvania, alleging that the school district had violated the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) by failing to provide a free appropriate public education in the least restrictive environment to children with disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The case was settled in April 1993, and the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to the following terms: PDE has failed to discharge its duty to provide general supervision over programs providing education and related services to students with disabilities in Pennsylvania.[SENTMARKER]PDE also agreed to create informational brochures about the types of supplementary aids and services that children can receive in a regular education classroom and how parents can seek assistance in obtaining these aids and service for their children.

gold_sents: In 2015, a transgender boy filed a lawsuit against his school district because they would not allow him to use the boys' bathroom.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the school district's motion to dismiss, but the appeals court reversed and remanded, and the district court has since granted a preliminary injunction allowing plaintiff access to the boy's bathroom.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court agreed to hear the school district's appeal in 2016, but later remanded the case after the Department of Education and Department of Justice withdrew their prior guidance on the issue.[SENTMARKER]The case was remanded to the district court to determine whether the plaintiff's graduation from high school rendered the case moot.[SENTMARKER]On May 22, 2018, the district court denied the defendant’s motion to dismiss.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff filed a second amended complaint on February 15, 2019, and a motion for summary judgment on March 26, 2019.[SENTMARKER]On August 9, 2019, the court granted the summary judgment; the defendant appealed the case.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.

gold_sents: On May 12, 2005, individual New York residents and the New York ACORN local chapter filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Easter District of New York.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sued Nassau County and the Village of Garden City under the Fair Housing Act, the Civil Rights Act of 1866, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, and the Equal Protection Clause of the 14th Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs asked the court to enjoin the defendants from proceeding with discriminatory zoning practices; to order Garden City to approve a proposed zoning that would allow for affordable housing; and to order the defendants to take all actions necessary to assure that the Social Service Site be redeveloped to maximize the availability of affordable and integrated housing.[SENTMARKER]On February 15, 2012, Judge Arthur D. pegasus_output_sents: On December 19, 2013, the Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this lawsuit in the Western District of Texas in the United States District Court for the Western district of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendant bank engaged in a pattern or practice of lending discrimination on the basis of national origin by charging Hispanic borrowers higher interest rates on unsecured consumer loans compared to similarly situated non-Hispanic white borrowers.[SENTMARKER]According to the complaint, FDSB did not properly instruct loan officers regarding their obligation to treat prospective customers without regard to national origin, and the bank failed to supervise or monitor the performance of its loan officers to ensure compliance with fair lending laws.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a consent order on December 19, 2013 requiring FDSB to implement a monitoring program designed to monitor the Bank's loans for potential disparities based on national origin.[SENTMARKER]FDSB also agreed to provide annual training to covered employees with respect to their responsibilities and obligations under ECOA and the loan policies adopted pursuant to it.

Among other things, the defendant's employees will have to participate in a fair lending training program and will be subject to monitoring and reporting requirements.[SENTMARKER]The defendant also has to place $687,000 into a settlement fund to compensate for monetary damages that aggrieved persons may have suffered.[SENTMARKER]The order terminates after three years if the defendant has complied during that time period.
pegasus_output_sents: The United States brought this action against Southport Bank in the United States District Court for the District of Wisconsin for discrimination based on race and national origin in its residential mortgage lending program.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that Southport charged hundreds of African-American and Hispanic wholesale borrowers higher origination fees than non-Hispanic white borrowers, not as a result of their creditworthiness or other objective criteria related to borrower risk, but because of their race or national origin.[SENTMARKER]In September 2008, Southport began to wind down its mortgage lending activities and after November of that year made virtually no new home mortgage loans.[SENTMARKER]On December 31, 2008, Southport closed ComCor.[SENTMARKER]Southport was required to collect, maintain, and report data with respect to certain loan terms and borrower information for residential loans, including the race and National origin of each wholesale residential loan borrower, pursuant to HMDA.

gold_sents: On June 8, 2015, civil detainees confined in the Tucson Sector of the U.S. Border Patrol filed a class action lawsuit, alleging violations of the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment and the APA due to inhumane and punitive conditions while they were detained in holding cells.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted a PI mandating that defendants must maintain conditions of confinement adequate for the detainees' physical needs and provide detainees with mats and blankets after 12 hours.[SENTMARKER]The Ninth Circuit affirmed the PI order.[SENTMARKER]In 2018 the plaintiffs filed a motion for partial summary judgment on the issue of defendants' obligation to provide raised beds for detainees held for any period requiring sleep; the district court denied this motion.[SENTMARKER]After a 7-day trial in January 2020, the district court held that these extended confinement conditions violated the Constitution and issued an order enjoining the defendants from holding detainees for longer than 48 unless they provided conditions of confinement that meet basic human needs.[SENTMARKER]This permanent injunction was ordered and has been in effect since April 2020.

gold_sents: Two San Francisco Bay Area fathers filed this class action in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after being detained for over 6 months in ICE custody without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction and class certification ordering that individuals detained pursuant to 8 U.S.C. § 1231(a)(6) pending a determination as to whether they can remain in the United States with “live claims”  before an adjudicative body cannot be detained for more than 180 days without a bond hearing.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed both orders to the Ninth Circuit, and on April 7, 2020, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the district court's order.[SENTMARKER]Following plaintiffs' motion to enforce the preliminary injunction, the court granted it in part, finding that the defendants had not substantially complied with certain requirements, but denied it in part.[SENTMARKER]As of April 16, 2021, this case is pending a writ of certiorari in front of the Supreme Court.

gold_sents: A group of Iranian refugees and their U.S. sponsors filed this class action lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California after the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) denied their refugee resettlement applications en masse in February 2018.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs applied for refugee resettlement through the Vienna, Austria-based Lautenberg-Specter program for Iranian religious minorities, but received mass denials with the sole explanation that they were denied "as a matter of discretion."[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that this violated the Lautenberg Amendment, which mandates that the denial state "to the maximum extent feasible, the reason for the denial," as well as Fifth Amendment due process and DHS's own regulations.[SENTMARKER]On July 2018, the court declared the denial notices unlawful, and ordered DHS to re-issue new notices.[SENTMARKER]As of June 3, 2020, the case is still ongoing.

gold_sents: On May 18, 2010, two organizations comprised of day laborers and/or predominately Latino immigrant workers filed a class action lawsuit in the Eastern District Court of New York under the First and Fourteenth Amendments against the Town of Oyster Bay.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU and LatinoJustice PRLDEF, sought injunctive relief, declaratory relief, and attorneys' fees and costs, claiming that the defendants, through the passage of an ordinance prohibiting the solicitation of labor from the town's streets and sidewalks, unlawfully prohibited speech related to employment and had a discriminatory animus against predominately Latino immigrant day laborers.[SENTMARKER]After defeating the defendant's partial motion for summary judgment due to lack of standing, plaintiff's motion for summary judgment was successful.[SENTMARKER]On September 3, 2015, the District Court enjoined the ordinance and declared it unconstitutional as it violated the first amendment.[SENTMARKER]On August 22, 2017, the Second Circuit affirmed the District Court's decision.[SENTMARKER]In July 2019, the court assessed attorney fees against the defendants, and the case closed later that year.
pegasus_output_sents: In 2009, the Town of Oyster Bay passed an ordinance prohibiting day laborers from standing near a public right-of-way from stopping or attempting to stop vehicles to solicit work, and drivers from picking up such laborers.[SENTMARKER]On May 18, 2010, two organizations of day laborers sued the Town and its Supervisor (together, the Town) in the district court, seeking to enjoin the town from enforcing the ordinance on the ground that the ordinance violated their constitutional rights to free speech and equal protection of the laws.[SENTMARKER]They immediately moved, on free-speech grounds only, for a temporary restraining order ("TRO") that would bar enforcement "until the hearing on [their]motion for preliminary injunction."[SENTMARKER]The district court entered a preliminary injunction as stipulated by the parties.[SENTMARKER]The Town then appealed to the Second Circuit.[SENTMARKER]The Second Circuit upheld the District Court's decision, and the case is now closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2009, the Town of Oyster Bay passed an ordinance prohibiting day laborers standing near a public right-of-way from stopping or attempting to stop vehicles to solicit work, and drivers from picking up such laborers.[SENTMARKER]On May 18, 2010, two organizations of day laborers sued the Town and its Supervisor (together, "the Town") in the district court, seeking to enjoin the town from enforcing the ordinance on the ground that the ordinance violated their constitutional rights to free speech and equal protection of the laws.[SENTMARKER]They immediately moved, on free-speech grounds only, for a temporary restraining order that would bar enforcement "until the hearing on [their]motion for preliminary injunction."[SENTMARKER]On October 19, 2011, the defendants issued their answer to the plaintiffs’ amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The defendants’ answer also raised the following four affirmative defenses: (1) The ordinance constitutes a reasonable time, place, and manner restriction; .[SENTMARKER](2) The ordinance does not violate the First Amendment; .[SENTMARKER](3) The speech in question constitutes commercial speech, but a substantial government interest; .[SENTMARKER](4) The ordinance is not unconstitutionally vague; and (5) The parties agreed to leave the preliminary injunction in place.[SENTMARKER]After receiving the Second Circuit’s ruling, however, the defendants appealed to the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of New York, where the defendants' motion for summary judgment was denied.

gold_sents: In 2018, Migrant Justice and four individual members of the organization filed this complaint in the United States District Court for the District of Vermont.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs alleged that the Department of Homeland Security and U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) implemented retaliatory policies in response to their activism on behalf of immigrant farm workers, including extensive surveillance and false imprisonment, in violation of their First Amendment Rights and that the Vermont Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) aided these practices by consistently and intentionally sharing personally identifying information about the plaintiffs with ICE in a manner that violated their Fourteenth Amendment Equal Protection rights.[SENTMARKER]On January 21, 2020, the plaintiffs and the DMV settled, and the DMV agreed to implement new protocols to protect against disclosing immigration and citizenship information with ICE.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs then settled with the remaining defendants on October 28, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The settlement agreement included $100,000 in damages, deferred action for the plaintiffs so they would not be deported, and ICE informing its employees that all immigrants are protected by the First Amendment.

gold_sents: In 2016, states and religiously affiliated healthcare providers filed this lawsuit in the Northern District of Texas.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Affordable Care Act's regulation prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex (which included gender identity and termination of pregnancy) violated the Administrative Procedure Act, Religious Freedom Restoration Act and constitutional rights.[SENTMARKER]In October 2016, plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction enjoining enforcement of this regulation, which was granted on December 31, 2016.[SENTMARKER]Defendants' motion to stay the preliminary injunction was denied in January 2017.[SENTMARKER]In May 2017, the defendants filed a motion for voluntary remand and stay, arguing that HHS should be given the opportunity to reconsider the regulation at issue in this case, which would conserve the resources of both parties and the court.[SENTMARKER]In July 2017, Judge O’Connor declined to remand the case, but imposed a stay of all proceedings while HHS reconsidered the regulation.[SENTMARKER]He clarified that the December 31, 2016 preliminary injunction order would be unaffected by the stay and would remain in full force and effect throughout the stay.[SENTMARKER]In December 2018, the stay was lifted, and the parties resumed litigating the case.[SENTMARKER]In September 2019, Judge O'Connor vacated the rule's challenged provisions.[SENTMARKER]An appeal is pending before the Fifth Circuit.

gold_sents: This was a prison medical care case filed in 2002 in the U.S. District Court for the District of New Jersey, seeking damages and an injunction against contract medical care providers and New Jersey corrections officials.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs that the New Jersey prison system was failing to treat them for Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]By the time the court adjudicated the class action issue, in May 2008, the New Jersey Department of Corrections had adopted major changes in how prisoners with HCV were treated; it updated its procedures to match those of the federal Bureau of Prisons, and "backscreened" all the prisoners willing to be screened for the virus.[SENTMARKER]Given that the injunctive relief requested by the plaintiffs was this same set of reforms, Judge Hillman denied the request for injunctive relief as moot.[SENTMARKER]As to two individual class members who had HCV, the court held there was sufficient evidence in the record to go to trial on their constitutional claims (though not on their Americans with Disabilities Act claims), and denied the state's motion for summary judgment.[SENTMARKER]In October 2009, the case settled for money damages.[SENTMARKER](However, it seems from some papers filed by one of the plaintiffs that he may never actually have received  his money.[SENTMARKER]But when he sought the assistance of the court in enforcing the settlement against his lawyer, Judge Hillman ruled that the court lacked jurisdiction, and directed him to file a collection action in state court.  )

pegasus_output_sents: On March 23, 2009, the U.S. District Court for the District of the Virgin Islands entered a consent decree (the "Conviction Decree") in order to correct an alleged systematic violation of constitutional rights through excessive force.[SENTMARKER]The Consent Decree was the result of a cooperative effort that evinced a commitment to constitutional policing on the part of the United States Department of Justice and the Territory ofthe Virgin Islands.[SENTMARKER]The parties also jointly requested the adoption of an action plan.[SENTMARKER]In the third quarter of 2013, the Office of the Independent Monitor ("OIM" or the "Monitor"), which was established in January 2010, issued its third quarterly report on the compliance with the Consent Decree.[SENTMARKER]The Monitor was required to report to the Court on a quarterly basis, detailing the Territory's compliance with and implementation of each substantive provision of the consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The Court held a full day hearing on November 18, 2013 to review a joint motion filed by the parties to extend the deadline for substantial compliance for another two years.[SENTMARKER]The final settlement of Consent Decree compliance can only be justified by demonstrating that constitutional behaviors and practices are in place and have been sustained for the two-year period required by the consent Decree.

gold_sents: In 1964, a group of African American families filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Louisiana.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant Jefferson Parish School Board had violated their rights under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment by continuing to segregate the school system.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief, mandated desegregation of the school system, and required that the defendants use busing to speed up the integration process.[SENTMARKER]The injunction remained in place for several decades.[SENTMARKER]In 2007, the School Board sought to implement a magnet school program in the hopes of boosting academics and increasing school diversity.[SENTMARKER]The parties jointly moved to supplement the desegregation plan to include the magnet school program, and the Court issued Consent Orders in 2008-2009 that enabled the School Board's plans.[SENTMARKER]However, issues arose in the following years with the School Board's implementation of the plan.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs argued that the defendants were using the Consent Orders as a pretext to conceal attempts to continue a system of racially segregated schools.[SENTMARKER]After the Consent Orders expired, the parties reached a settlement agreement and the Court declared Jefferson Parish Schools unitary in 2011.

gold_sents: On April 29, four individuals with disabilities and Disability Rights New York filed a complaint against Andrew Cuomo, the Governor of New York State.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the absence of live televised American Sign Language (ASL) interpretation in Governor Cuomo’s daily televised briefings on COVID-19 discriminated against populations with disabilities residing in New York by failing to provide a live ASL interpreter.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, declaring the lack of ASL interpretation as a violation under the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs also sought a TRO and preliminary injunction requiring the defendant to immediately include live in-frame ASL interpretation for all briefings addressed to New York residents.[SENTMARKER]The preliminary injunction was granted on May 11, and the defendant was ordered to immediately implement live, in-frame ASL interpretation for his daily press briefings.[SENTMARKER]The case is ongoing.
pegasus_output_sents: On May 12, 2020, a group of individuals with disabilities filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District Of New York, alleging that the county violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Minnesota Human Rights Act (HRA) by failing to provide an in-frame American Sign Language (ASL) interpreter during televised broadcast briefings.[SENTMARKER]The district court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on May 11, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The Eighth Circuit affirmed the district court's grant of summary judgment for the county, holding in relevant part that the ADA and HRA did not require the county to provide the ASL interpreter at every meeting because based on the interpretation services that were provided the county "effectively communicated" the relevant information to the plaintiffs at the large-group meetings.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On April 8, 2014, the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Rhode Island alleging that Rhode Island violated the ADA by segregating individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities in sheltered workshops and facility-based day programs that denied them the opportunity to associate with those who did not have a disability.[SENTMARKER]On April 9, 2014, the District Court approved a Consent Decree where Rhode Island agreed to, among other things, provide employment planning services to individuals with developmental and intellectual disabilities designed to encourage and assist them in working in integrated working environments, provide state support and services for those working in integrated settings and those making the transition to those settings, programs to educate relevant individuals about the programs and benefits that the Rhode Island offers to those working in integrated settings.[SENTMARKER]Rhode Island must also implement policies regarding the services required by the Consent Decree, train its personnel in the new procedures and working with individuals with disabilities, and Rhode Island must help sheltered workshops change their structure to become integrated working environments.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 11, 2013, the United States Department of Justice (DOJ) filed this civil rights suit in the District Court for the District ofRhode Island.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the Rhode Island Department of Education (RIDE) violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Supreme Court's decision in Olmstead v. L.C.[SENTMARKER]by failing to serve individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (I/DD) in the most integrated day activity service setting appropriate for their needs, and by placing transition-age youth at serious risk of segregation.[SENTMARKER]On January 1, 2015, the parties entered into a consent decree.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree required the State to develop and implement an Employment First Policy, provide documentation that staff involved in the delivery of services and supports, as identified by Section IX (2) and (3) of the Consent Decree, are being trained to established competency levels, and provide services to non-public special education schools participating in the training that is being provided.[SENTMARKER]The Court Monitor reported that while progress had been made by the State in addressing the provisions of the Court Order, additional steps needed to be taken to fully comply with the terms and conditions of the consent decree, and the State did not appear to be in full compliance with the Court Monitor's recommendations.[SENTMARKER]On September 30, 2015, the Court Judge entered a final judgment in favor of the State.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On April 9, 2014, the United States Department of Justice, Civil Rights Division, and the Rhode Island Department of Social Services filed this consent decree in the U.N.[SENTMARKER]district court for the District of Providence, Rhode Island.[SENTMARKER]The consent decree was designed to change the nature and operation of day and employment services furnished to individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDD) who receive publicly financed supports.[SENTMARKER]Under the terms of the consent decree, the State made a sustained commitment to transform its service system to provide individuals with IDD the training and support they need to: (a) become employed in competitive, integrated jobs working alongside people without disabilities and paid a minimum wage or higher; and (b) fully participate in community activities of their own choosing with friends, families, and other members of society.[SENTMARKER]The plan should include requirements for effective outreach and in-reach, transition, discovery, and vocational and situational assessment for service recipients and their families.

gold_sents: On June 20, 2018, three immigrant parents separated from their children filed a civil action against various federal agencies and officials in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia for immediate reunification with their children.The plaintiffs were detained after crossing the United States-Mexico border without inspection with young accompanying children, seeking asylum.[SENTMARKER]After plaintiffs were apprehended at the border, the children were separated under the “zero-tolerance” immigration policy announced April 6, 2018, which criminally prosecuted adult entrants crossing the border illegally and placed accompanying minors in custody of the government.[SENTMARKER]All three plaintiffs crossed the border prior to the Executive Order issued on June 20, 2018, which allowed immigrant parents and children apprehended at the border to remain together during the pendency of their proceedings.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged interference of family integrity in violation of Due Process, and sought preliminary and permanent injunctions to immediately reunite plaintiffs with their children.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs obtained preliminary relief and were (along with another parent who joined the case later to prevent separation from her daughter) ultimately re-united with their children.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In early 2011, an electronic communication service provider that had received a National Security Letter (NSL) from the federal government filed a petition to set aside the NSL in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.[SENTMARKER]The recipient asked the court for declaratory and injunctive relief, claiming that a nondisclosure provision of the NSL Statute, 18 U.S.C. § 2709, violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]On March 14, 2013, U.S. District Judge Susan Illston granted the petition to set aside the NSL, declaring that § 2709 violated the First Amendment.[SENTMARKER]The government was therefore enjoined from issuing NSLs under § 2709 or from enforcing the nondisclosure provision in this or any other case.[SENTMARKER]The government appealed the decision to the Ninth Circuit, but while the appeal was pending, Congress amended § 2709 and 18 U.S.C. § 3511 as part of the USA FREEDOM Act of 2015.[SENTMARKER]The district court and Ninth Circuit upheld the constitutionality of the revised § 2709 and § 3511.[SENTMARKER]But the district court held that the government failed to justify nondisclosure in one case involving the recipient, and the government found that nondisclosure was no longer required in another case involving the recipient.[SENTMARKER]As a result, the recipient could reveal itself as CREDO Mobile.

gold_sents: This class action was about whether the City of New York improperly denied federally sponsored cash assistance to qualified New York City residents under a program implemented by the city in the late 1990s.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs each claimed to be qualified welfare beneficiaries who had been improperly denied assistance by one of New York City’s new job centers in violation of the fourteenth amendment guarantee of due process, the city’s obligations under 7 U.S.C. §2020 (the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program—then referred to as Food Stamps) and 42 U.S.C. §1396 (Medicaid), in addition to violating state law; the plaintiffs sought class certification for all similarly situated New York City residents, as well as declaratory and injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York on December 16, 1998, with Judge William H. Pauley presiding.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a temporary restraining order on the same day directing the city to provide emergency food stamps and cash assistance to the named plaintiffs.[SENTMARKER]The court granted a preliminary injunction in-part to the plaintiffs on January 21, 1999.[SENTMARKER]The court ordered the city to (1) allow applicants for public assistance to apply for benefits the first day they visit a job center, (2) cease conversion of income support centers to job centers without a formal hearing, (3) make eligibility requirements for food stamps and Medicaid separately from the eligibility determination from cash assistance, (4) send applicants timely notice of the city’s decision on whether they qualify for benefits, and (5) form a corrective plan for achieving its policy goals while also meeting the needs of public assistance applicants.[SENTMARKER]The city moved to vacate the preliminary injunction on December 10, 1999, after procuring more evidence surrounding the efficacy of the job centers in achieving their welfare obligations.[SENTMARKER]Meanwhile, the State of New York moved to dismiss the complaint against them for failure to state a claim.[SENTMARKER]Judge Pauley denied both motions and granted the plaintiff’s motion for class certification on July 21, 2000.[SENTMARKER]The court entered a permanent injunction in favor of the plaintiffs on December 30, 2004.[SENTMARKER]The permanent injunction directed both the city and state to: (i) provide expedited food stamp service to eligible applications within 7 days; .[SENTMARKER](ii) separately process applications for food stamps when the applications for cash assistance are denied or withdrawn; .[SENTMARKER](iii) send notices to applicants confirming voluntary withdrawals for Medicaid in accord with 42 C.F.R. 435.913 and document such withdrawals pursuant to 7 C.F.R. 273.2(c)(6); and (iv) provide adequate and timely notice by correctly completing certain documentation.[SENTMARKER]The injunction also required the state to supervise the city and make sure it met the obligations of the injunction.[SENTMARKER]On January 13, 2005, the plaintiffs moved for reconsideration of the part of the December order in which the court concluded that 8 N.Y.C.R.R.[SENTMARKER]§ 387.8(a)(2)(i)(a) did not confer a privately enforceable right of action and that plaintiffs’ claim under New York Social Services Law § 133 was barred by the doctrine of sovereign immunity.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the motion on February 14, 2005.[SENTMARKER]Final judgement was entered on December 14, 2005; the court also granted the plaintiffs declaratory judgment.[SENTMARKER]Both the state and the city appealed the permanent injunction to the Second Circuit on January 12, 2006, but the city dropped its appeal.[SENTMARKER]On October 31, 2007, the Second Circuit reversed the district court, ruling that the state did not have a non-delegable duty to administer the decentralized Medicaid and Food Stamp programs, the state’s efforts in supervising the city since the permanent injunction was issued were adequate, and the district court exceeded its authority by issuing a permanent injunction in light of New York State’s affirmative supervisory steps it had taken to assure compliance.[SENTMARKER]In a series of stipulations and orders from January 31, 2007 to July 22, 2011, the City of New York agreed to pay a total of $2,920,675.94 to plaintiffs for attorney fees and costs sought; the state agreed to pay a further $639,918.98.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: On September 13, 2013, an African American inmate in the Arizona State Prison Complex in Tucson filed this lawsuit against the State of Arizona and the Arizona Department of Correction in the District of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]He sued under 42 U.S.C. § 1983.[SENTMARKER]The inmate alleged that the prison segregated him by race, in violation of the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement on December 22, 2015, under which the defendants would narrowly limit racial consideration in prison housing and employment opportunities, and pay $5,000 in monetary damages to plaintiff as well as $195,000 to plaintiff’s counsel in attorneys’ fees and costs.
pegasus_output_sents: On September 13, 2013, an African-American inmate at the Arizona State prison complex in Tucson, Arizona, filed a civil rights suit against the State of Arizona alleging racial discrimination in the use of segregation.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that African-Americans, Native Americans, and Latino inmates were housed in separate housing units based on their race.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on December 22, 2015, and the parties filed an amended Stipulation for Payment of Monetary Damages (Doc.[SENTMARKER]114-1) in February 2016.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement an integrated housing program (IHP) to foster racial equality among inmates by assigning inmates 7 to Santa Monica Blvd., with the intention that doing so will enhance rehabilitation and security interests.[SENTMARKER]The parties also agreed to develop policies, procedures, and practices necessary to implement the IHP.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On September 13, 2013, an African-American inmate of the Arizona State prison complex in Tucson, Arizona, filed a civil rights lawsuit against the Arizona Departments of Corrections (ADC) and the Governor of the State of Arizona.[SENTMARKER]He alleged that the defendants' policy of racial segregation in the Tucson Prison Complex violated his right to equal protection under the Fourteenth Amendment of the United States Constitution.[SENTMARKER]He was transferred to the Santa Rita Unit on November 4, 2013, and shares a 23 bunk with an inmate of same race.[SENTMARKER]The court granted his motion for declaratory and injunctive relief and ordered the defendants to pay his attorney's fees and costs.[SENTMARKER]The defendants appealed, and the case was settled on December 22, 2015.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: In 2005, a group of California prisoners with mental illness filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of California against the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation alleging that the prison system's policies regarding prisoners with mental disabilities violated the ADA.[SENTMARKER]The parties settled in 2015 and the court retained jurisdiction to enforce the terms of the settlement.
pegasus_output_sents: This is an action for relief from Defendants' violation of Plaintiff's civil rights under the Americans with disabilities Act and Rehabilitation Act.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff is an individual with a psychiatric disability, and an inmate incarcerated at the California Medical Facility.[SENTMARKER]In addition, defendants contend that the claims raised in Hecker are covered within Coleman, and that they may be appropriately and more efficiently resolved via Program Guide discussion and application.[SENTMARKER]On November 17, 2006, the defendants filed a Rule 12(b) and (f) motion to dismiss the case.[SENTMARKER]The parties did not reach a resolution.[SENTMARKER]On February 3, 2006, the Coleman Special Master issued his report and 2 recommendation concerning the Program Guide, concluding that the parties’ 3 concerning alleged disability discrimination could not be resolved by the Special Master at that time.[SENTMARKER]The case continues today.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On June 12, 2007, a class of prisoners with mental illness filed a class action suit in the United States District Court for the Eastern District Of California alleging discrimination in the treatment of inmates with psychiatric disabilities.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement on June 22, 2007.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to implement appropriate remedies to protect the Plaintiff class, without requiring additional, 20 costly litigation with results that would be uncertain.[SENTMARKER]The settlement is subject to court approval.

gold_sents: In 2014, Disability Rights Florida filed this complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiff alleged that certain inmates with mental illness at Dade Correctional Institution had been subject to torture, beatings, verbal harassment and food deprivation in violation of their Eighth Amendment Rights.[SENTMARKER]They also alleged that these inmates had received insufficient care in violation of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Federal Rehabilitation Act. Disability Rights Florida requested declaratory and injunctive relief to deem these practices unlawful and unconstitutional, and assurance that such practices would not continue.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a settlement agreement which required improved conditions for prisoners and ran through November 2017.[SENTMARKER]Subsequent litigation in this case resulted from its consolidation with a related civil rights case seeking monetary damages.[SENTMARKER]That portion of the litigation settled for $4.5 million in 2018.[SENTMARKER]As of July 2020, the court retains jurisdiction to enforce the settlement agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: Disability Rights Florida filed this suit in September 2014 in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida on behalf of persons with mental illness confined by the State of Florida at Dade correctional institution (Dade CI).[SENTMARKER]The suit alleged that the defendants violated the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) by failing to protect the rights of those confined by Dade CI.[SENTMARKER]The parties reached a private settlement agreement in May 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to pay the Plaintiff reasonable attorneys' fees and costs after the case was dismissed with prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The District Court retained continuing jurisdiction in the case.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On January 17, 2018, the Plaintiff filed this suit in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida, alleging that the Defendants violated the rights of inmates with serious mental illness by failing to provide constitutionally adequate mental health care.[SENTMARKER]The Plaintiff's suit alleged that the Defendant's actions and inactions caused continuing violations of the Eighth Amendment rights of its clients and constituents housed at Dade CI.[SENTMARKER]On January 31, 2017, the parties entered into a settlement agreement.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed that the case would be dismissed with prejudice on May 31, 2017 unless the plaintiff filed a timely Motion to Reopen the case alleging breach of the agreement.[SENTMARKER]On November 30, 2017, the case was re-opened and the parties agreed to extend the settlement agreement until January 31, 2018.

gold_sents: Deaf inmate at the Georgia Department of Corrections filed lawsuit for injunctive relief in the form of communication aids and damages for pain and suffering.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed following a show cause order from the judge suggesting that case should be consolidated with a nearly identical case.
pegasus_output_sents: On February 15, 2017, a prisoner filed a complaint against the Georgia Department of Corrections alleging that the prison had violated his rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Religious Land Use and Institutionalized Persons Act (RLP) by failing to provide him with adequate medical care and food.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the prisoner was held in solitary confinement for a week at a time.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to dismiss, and the case was closed on February 15, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The defendants then filed a motion to reopen the case, which was denied.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed and the parties have agreed to settle the case.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In August 2016, a deaf inmate filed a complaint against the Georgia Department of Corrections (GDOC) alleging that GDOC violated his constitutional and statutory rights under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and the Rehabilitation Act (R&A) by failing to provide him with adequate food, sanitation, and clothing while he was held in solitary confinement for a week.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated his ADA and R&A rights by denying him access to food, water, and other facilities.[SENTMARKER]On September 13, 2018, the court granted Defendants' motion for leave to file a second amended complaint.[SENTMARKER]The parties have 90 days from the date of this order to complete discovery.

gold_sents: In 2016, two Missouri Medicaid recipients filed this lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Missouri after being denied medication to treat their Hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that Missouri Department of Social Services and MO HealthNet denied medically necessary treatment to Medicaid beneficiaries with Hepatitis C, discriminated against similarly situated Medicaid beneficiaries, failed to provide "reasonably prompt" treatment, violated due process, and violated the American with Disabilities Act.[SENTMARKER]In November 2017, MO HealthNet modified its policies and the case was dismissed as moot without prejudice.[SENTMARKER]The case closed in November 2017.
pegasus_output_sents: On July 21, 2017, a group of Medicaid recipients with Hepatitis C filed this lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Western District Of Missouri.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the Defendants' policies and prior authorization criteria exclude them from medically necessary, direct-acting antiviral treatment while providing the same treatment to other Medicaid enrollees with hepatitis C.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' request for a preliminary injunction prohibiting Defendants from requiring three months of negative drug and alcohol screens prior to submitting requests for DAA approval.[SENTMARKER]The Court found that a material factual dispute exists regarding the medical necessity of treating all Hepatitis C patients with DAAs regardless of fibrosis score.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: This case was filed on behalf of enrollees in the Missouri Medicaid program, also known as MO HealthNet, who are infected with Hepatitis C, a serious and communicable disease that can cause severe liver scarring, liver damage, cancer, and death.[SENTMARKER]Without this treatment, damage to enrollees’ livers grows more severe and the risk of complications from the disease increases.

gold_sents: Four incarcerated women alleged that their First, Fourth, Fifth, Eighth, and Fourteenth Amendment rights were violated by being housed in the same facilities as transgender women.[SENTMARKER]After years of litigation, the claims were eventually dismissed.

On September 25, 2017, the Court ordered that this case bebated pending the resolution of ongoing settlement negotiations.[SENTMARKER]On May 31, the case was returned to active status.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in April 2019.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On December 30, 2016, a group of female inmates in the custody of the Federal Bureau Of Prisons (BOP) filed this lawsuit against the BOP.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the recent changes to rules and regulations that authorize male prison inmates to be housed in the same facilities that house female inmates violated their constitutional right to bodily privacy and threatened their physical and mental health and safety.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunctive relief on December 30, 2017.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a permanent injunction on January 2, 2017.

gold_sents: This case was filed by a trans woman incarcerated in a men's prison in Washington State on September 5, 2017 in the District Court for the Western District of Washington.[SENTMARKER]She alleges that the blanket policy in the Washington Department of Correction denying prisoners access to gender affirming surgery amounts to a violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments.[SENTMARKER]She is represented by the ACLU, and is seeking injunctive relief.[SENTMARKER]The parties came to a preliminary settlement agreement on March 20, 2020, and proceedings were stayed for 180 days in an attempt to implement the agreement.
pegasus_output_sents: In October 2017, a transgender female inmate, Nonnie Lotusflower, filed this lawsuit against the Washington State Dept.[SENTMARKER]of Corrections, seeking declaratory and injunctive relief for her gender dysphoria, including surgical treatment.[SENTMARKER]The parties recently executed a settlement agreement, under which Ms. Lotusflower will receive the medical treatment she 2 seeks if a professional evaluator determines that she is ready for surgery and that it is medically necessary.[SENTMARKER]In March 2020, the parties asked the Court to enter a stay of this litigation for 180 days to allow them to implement the terms of the settlement prior to dismissing the case with prejudice.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On March 20, 2019, the ACLU of Washington filed this suit against the Washington State Dept.[SENTMARKER]of Corrections in the United States District Court for the Western district of Washington.[SENTMARKER]The complaint alleged that the defendants violated the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments by denying gender-reassignment surgery to a transgender inmate.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the defendants' motion to stay the case for 180 days.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to provide the inmate with gender affirming surgery within 30 days of receiving the Evaluator's written report.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

gold_sents: Three indigent persons charged with crimes filed a class action lawsuit in Skagit County Superior Court against the City of Mount Vernon and the City of Burlington alleging defendants failed to provide adequate assistance of counsel.[SENTMARKER]The Cities jointly contracted with two attorneys to handle all public defense assistance cases, and each attorney handled over 1,000 cases per year.[SENTMARKER]The Court found the plaintiffs established their rights were systematically deprived and the Cities were responsible for the deprivation.[SENTMARKER]The Court granted injunctive relief requiring the City of Mount Vernon and City of Burlington re-evaluate their contract for the provision of public defense services and hire one part-time public defense supervisor.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 2011, a group of indigent defendants filed this lawsuit in the Skagit County Superior Court in order to challenge the constitutional adequacy of the public defense system provided by the City of Mt Vernon 17 and the city of Burlington.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants' contract with two attorneys allowed each attorney to handle up to 13 l,200 cases per year even though such a caseload is three times the maximum allowable 14 amoWtt for a full-time public defender pursuant to standards established by the WSBA.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a settlement in which the defendants agreed to pay the plaintiffs more for their services.[SENTMARKER]The case was dismissed on July 5, 2011, and the case was transferred to federal court.

gold_sents: On November 13, 2018, CNN and CNN’s chief White House correspondent Jim Acosta sued President Trump and several senior members of his administration for violating his First and Fifth Amendment rights by revoking his White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]under The plaintiffs sued under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the Declaratory Judgments Act, arguing that defendants violated the Constitution and APA when they revoked Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 13, 2018, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction, requesting that the court require the defendants to restore Acosta’s White House press credentials.[SENTMARKER]On November 16, the court granted the plaintiffs’ motion.[SENTMARKER]Plaintiffs voluntarily dismissed the case on November 19, 2018 after the Trump administration returned Acosta's White House press credentials to him.[SENTMARKER]The case is now closed.

oreo_pegasus_output_sents: On June 26, 2020, a group of Orthodox Jewish and Catholic Congregations filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Northern District Of New York against the New York Governor, New York Mayor, and the State Attorney General.[SENTMARKER]The plaintiffs sought a temporary restraining order (with notice) to restrain the defendants from enforcing the Governor's orders in a manner infringing on Plaintiffs' religious services.[SENTMARKER]The court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction on May 26, 2020.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed to a permanent injunction on June 26, 2020.

gold_sents: The NAACP and Detroit students and parents sued the Detroit school board and other state defendants in federal court, alleging unconstitutional segregation in Detroit's schools.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that Detroit's schools were illegally segregated, in part because of decisions made by the school board to create and maintain and segregated system.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that a Detroit-only remedy would be insufficient, and ordered a busing plan that would have affected students in city schools and 53 largely white suburban school districts, but the Supreme Court rejected this plan and a Detroit-only remedy was implemented.
pegasus_output_sents: In December 1970, a class action was brought against the Detroit School Board, the State of Michigan, and the Detroit Federation of Teachers alleging that the Detroit Public Schools were segregated on the basis of race.[SENTMARKER]The district court found that certain conduct on the part of the defendants fostered segregation in the Detroit school system and violated the Fourteenth Amendment rights of Detroit school children.[SENTMARKER]In September 1981, the district court ordered the parties to submit plans to desegregate the Detroit public schools.[SENTMARKER]The parties agreed on the amount which the state defendants would contribute to the cost of providing for the educational remedies.[SENTMARKER]In June 1981, the Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed in part.[SENTMARKER]The case is closed.
oreo_pegasus_output_sents: In 1910, the black population of Detroit was only 1.2% of the total population of the city.[SENTMARKER]The district court ruled that a Detroit only integration plan would be insufficient to cure the unconstitutional segregation found to have been imposed in the Detroit city schools.[SENTMARKER]The state defendants defaulted in this obligation, however, and the district court ordered a student assignment plan that would encompass Detroit and 53 suburban school districts.[SENTMARKER]The Supreme Court granted certiorari and reversed in part.
